raw_text:
US firm 'bids for Lacroix label'
 
 A US firm has said it is in final negotiations with luxury goods group LVMH to buy the loss-making Christian Lacroix haute-couture house.
 
 Paris-based LVMH has been selling non-core businesses and focusing on its most profitable labels including Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton. Privately-held Falic Group bought two cosmetics brands, Hard Candy and Urban Decay, from LVMH in early 2003. The Florida company also own a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US. LVMH refused to comment on the reports. But one of the three brothers behind the Falic Group said the firm had also held talks with the designer Christian Lacroix, and wished to retain him. "We are buying his name," Simon Falic told the Reuters news agency. "We have plans to increase the exposure of the brand and increase the volume of business."
llama3.2:1b: A US firm has bid for luxury goods group LVMH's Christian Lacroix haute-couture house in final negotiations, with the company selling non-core businesses and focusing on profitable labels like Moet & Chandon.
The Falic Group, a privately-held cosmetics company owned by three brothers, had previously purchased two of LVMH's brands, Hard Candy and Urban Decay, as well as a US duty-free store chain.
llama3.2:3b: A US firm is in final negotiations with LVMH to buy Christian Lacroix haute-couture house, as part of a strategy to sell non-core businesses and focus on more profitable labels.
The Falic Group, which owns Hard Candy and Urban Decay, has expressed interest in retaining designer Christian Lacroix and plans to increase brand exposure and volume.
gemma2:2b: A US firm, Falic Group, is in final negotiations to buy the luxury fashion house Christian Lacroix from LVMH, potentially for a loss-making label.
Falic Group has experience buying non-core brands and owns duty free stores.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US luxury goods group LVMH is reportedly preparing to buy the Christian Lacroix haute-couture house, with a focus on its core brands like Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton.

Falic Group, which previously owned two cosmetics brands and 90 duty-free stores in the US, has also made private talks with the designer Christian Lacroix to preserve his name and increase exposure for the brand.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A US company is in final negotiations to buy luxury goods group LVMH's Christian Lacroix fashion house, which it considers a non-core business.
The firm aims to improve exposure and boost sales for the designer name.
qwen2.5:3b: A US firm is in final negotiations to buy loss-making Christian Lacroix haute-couture house from luxury goods group LVMH, which has been selling non-core businesses focusing on profitable labels like Moët & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton.
Privately-held Falic Group bought two cosmetics brands (Hard Candy and Urban Decay) from LVMH in 2003; they also own a chain of US duty-free stores.

Simon Falic, one of the three brothers behind Falic Group, stated they are acquiring Christian Lacroix's name with plans to increase brand exposure and business volume, despite LVMH refusing to comment on reports.
opencoder:1.5b:
US firm 'bids for Lacroix label'

A US firm has said it is in final negotiations with luxury goods group LVMH to buy the loss-making Christian Lacroix haute-couture house.
Paris-based LVMH has been selling non-core businesses and focusing on its most profitable labels including Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton.
The Florida company also owns a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US.
LVMH refused to comment on the reports, but one of the three brothers behind the Falic Group said the firm had held talks with the designer Christian Lacroix, and wished to retain him.
"We are buying his name," Simon Falic told the Reuters news agency, suggesting an increase in the brand's exposure and business volume.
smollm:1.7b: The US firm is in final negotiations with luxury goods group LVMH to buy the loss-making Christian Lacroix haute-couture house.
This move is a strategic step towards expanding its market share in the fashion industry, which has been dominated by European brands like Hermès and Chanel.
The company's focus on its most profitable labels, including Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton, will help it to increase its market share further.
The US firm also owns a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US, which is another way for the company to expand its presence in the country.
The Florida company has also own a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US, which will help it to increase its market share further.
The brothers behind the Falic Group said that they had also held talks with Christian Lacroix, and wished to retain him as part of their deal.
This move is likely to increase the exposure of the brand and increase the volume of business for the company.

The company has been selling non-core businesses and focusing on their profitable labels, including Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton.
Additionally, they sold duty-free stores and purchased two cosmetics brands, Hard Candy and Urban Decay, from LVMH in 2003.
One of the brothers of the group that acquired these brands stated that LVMH is considering talks with Christian Lacroix to retain him, planning to increase brand exposure and business volume.

Private labeling firm Falic Group owns a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US, and the Florida-based company is also reportedly interested in purchasing Lacroix's name.

The Florida company Falic Group also owns a chain of duty free stores in the US, and LVMH had refused to comment on the reports.

The Florida-based Falic Group, which owns a chain of 90 duty free stores in the US, also wants to retain the designer's name and increase the brand's exposure and volume of business.

granite3.1-dense:2b: A US-based company, Falic Group, led by brothers, is in advanced negotiations with luxury conglomerate LVMH to acquire the struggling Christian Lacroix haute-couture line.
This move aligns with LVMH's strategy of divesting non-core businesses and concentrating on profitable brands like Moet & Chandon champagne and Louis Vuitton.

LVMH has not commented on these rumors.
